repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This is probably not the right way to do it. But anyway, I'm to tired too think of the right way right now and I think it is an interesting discussion: determine the injection language of tree-sitter parsers using `vim.filetype`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7189118/149832763-d498b383-de24-4305-9a5b-eea3fcb8e764.png)

This heuristic:

- could be an option on creation of language tree
- could be an over writable function in language tree module (and filetype.lua,_ft_by_extension just one possible implementation that can be chosen)
- this behavior could be connected to special directive that explicitly requests filetype.lua
- this behavior could be connected to special capture that explicitly requests filetype.lua (e.g. `@extension`)
- it could be documented that filetype.lua is used
- we could use vim global variables like `g:markdown_fenced_language` (I'm really not a fan)

Related https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/2131

 Disclaimer: I don't know about rationale and the discussions about filetype.lua so it's possible I'm totally abusing it.

comment_data.body: totally a hard-coded hack. just a demo what could be done. this could go into `_get_injections` for a `@extension` capture.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -133,6 +133,13 @@ function LanguageTree:parse()
 
   for lang, injection_ranges in pairs(injections_by_lang) do
     local has_lang = language.require_language(lang, nil, true)
+    local lang_by_extension = require'vim.filetype'._ft_by_extension(lang)

comment_regular_data.body:
We're very much open to having `filetype.lua` serve more purposes than just `setf <foo>` on `BufLoad`.

(Another is what [plenary.filetype](https://github.com/nvim-lua/plenary.nvim#plenaryfiletype) does. The main point right now is a discussion among the different stakeholders -- of which nvim-treesitter definitely is one -- about the best refactor/API to make everybody happy.)
you're right. probably this should just be done as a plugin feature

No, that's not what I'm saying :) I'm just saying if we do it (which we probably want to), we should do it _right_ ;) (For example, exposing not just the simple extension matching but also the more complicated pattern and file contents matching, e.g., for `fish`.)
The API should be explicit enough that you get exactly what you'd expect to happen which is challenging.

We're actively working on making `vim.filetype.match(path, bufnr)` return the resolved filetype instead of setting it (see #18241 and linked PRs). The question now is whether that is enough for treesitter injections, which are not files loaded into a buffer?

@clason we actually need the internal `extension -> filetype` mapping of this module (not path to ft, even though we could create a fake path). Would still think that it would be good for user configuration to have a lever to change the behavior of injections.

OK, I'll see how to best expose this without unnecessarily increasing the API surface.

(Note that users can configure the filetype detection with `vim.filetype.add()`, so a static table is not enough.)
but `vim.filetype.add` can update the extension table. So that's all we would need for that usecase.

> but `vim.filetype.add` can update the extension table. So that's all we would need for that usecase.

Yes, but we want it so _only_ `vim.filetype.add` can update the table, which means we can't just make it public ;)
but `_ft_by_extension` just does the lookup in the internal table. This answer would be sufficient for most usecases

Could you take a look at #18895? That should address this use case:
* `vim.filetype.match({filename = 'injection.cxx'})` for code block markers;
* `vim.filetype.match({contents = injected_content})` for more complicated blocks, e.g., shell scripts or LaTeX.

(Note that the "naked" extension table will not help here, since extensions like `cpp` or `tex` are not mapped directly to filetypes but to functions that disambiguate based on global variables and contents.)

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24659 has added a fallback to `injection.language` to check for filetype as well as (tree-sitter) language name, which gets us a long way already (since you can always register custom "filetypes" via `vim.treesitter.language.register()`).

Do we still need/want a more complex lookup that (a) adds a fallback to check for extension and/or (b) runs the whole `vim.filetype.match` engine on the injection contents?

(I feel (a) is feasible -- though not sure how widely useful -- but (b) is out of scope for core, at least until an actual compelling use case is raised.)
I think it's fine now as plugins/users can now apply their own logic. nvim-treesitter now uses filetype.lua to decide one the parser

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: tree-sitter: injection language base on filetype.lua
